39 Margareta Matovic, writing of the Essanay Studio film character “Sweedie, the silly Swedish maid” in Edwardian Chicago, accounts for her vast popularity with cinema audiences by their need to ridicule and thus set constraints on an economically independent woman. It is the patriarchal order, for Matovic, that should be “blamed” for this kind of humor. This account, however, tells us little about who was consuming the “Sweedie” films and what meanings audiences attached to this character, and an abstraction such as “patriarchy” sheds little light on the specific discursive context that made this character funny (Matovic, Margareta, “Swedish-American Women in Lake View,” in Peasant Maids–City Women: From the European Countryside to Urban America, ed.
